message: We should ideally set these threads as daemon to avoid the possibility of hanging shutdowns in clients/server. This requires associating a thread factory with the executor as we do in the server’s `KafkaScheduler`. This will also get rid of the requirement to formally close the metrics object in all the tests (although I think close is a good practice regardless if we are associating a thread pool with metrics).

message:
I'd like to suggest a revision of this. What do you think? :smile:

```
The `render` helper can also cache individual templates rendered for a collection.
It can even one up the previous example with `each` by reading all cache
templates at once instead of one by one. This is done automatically if the template
rendered by the collection includes `cache` call. Take a collection that renders a
`products/_product.html.erb` partial for each element:

render products

If `products/_product.html.erb` starts with a `cache` call like so:

<% cache product do %>
  <%= product.name %>
<% end %>

All the cached templates from previous renders will be fetched at once with much
greater speed. There's more info on how to make your templates [eligible for collection caching](http://api.rubyonrails.org/classes/ActionView/Template/Handlers/ERB.html#method-i-resource_cache_call_pattern).
```

message:
Additionally, I think the very beginning of this guide could be improved. Right now it says:

> This guide will teach you what you need to know about avoiding that expensive round-trip to your database and returning what you need to return to the web clients in the shortest time possible.
>
> After reading this guide, you will know:
> * Page and action caching (moved to separate gems as of Rails 4).
> * Fragment caching.
> * Alternative cache stores.
> * Conditional GET support.

Since this is a guide, I think we can take a wider approach and introduce what caching is and why is beneficial. For instance:

> Caching means to store the content generated by a request and to reuse it when responding to similar requests.
 
> Caching is arguably one of the hardest problems in computer science.
> At the same time, it is the most effective way to boost the performance of an application. 
> Through caching, web sites running on a single server with a single database can sustain a load of thousands of concurrent users.
 
> Rails provides a set of caching methods out of the box.
> This guide will teach you the scope and purpose of each one of them.
> Master these techniques and you will be able to scale your Rails applications, serving million of views without incurring in exorbitant delays or server bills.
label: Documentation

message: It doesn't look like we save this in the cache anywhere (nor do we at L925). I guess the thinking is that we'll just wait and update it at the next loop anyway.However, the problem is that this makes two subsequent calls to get_info() return different data if use_cache isn't consistent. I dunno if that happens anywhere, but it'd be something I would try to avoid for the future when someone puts another call somewhere in a cleanup routine or something. Because you might've headed down a path based on non-cached info, and then fail to clean up (or do anything else) based on the cached info.

hmm, maybe we should use `os.rename` instead of `shutil.move` here?

- POSIX requires rename in the same file system to be atomic
https://docs.python.org/3/library/os.html#os.rename

- shutil.move seems to be more general and work on different file system, but i don't think that kind of file rename is atomic anymore and therefore defeats the purpose of writing to a temp file first and rename. In fact, I don't think we want to support renaming to a file in a different filesystem?

message:
Yes, I hesitated back&forth. Adding a decoder, means adding a bunch of code everywhere to automatically load it up etc.. For a single pretty niche (currently) use case.
Adding it as tokenizer, is defendable as you said, and makes things simpler for all utils. It's not however really a tokenizer (since it takes `logits` not `input_ids`). The good thing, is that for the pipeline it should roughly be seen as an implementation detail, not really something users should depend on  (if it's `tokenizer`).

I don't like adding `kwargs` without careful thought (pipelines are already a kwarg mess, adding on top is something worth at least a pause).

- Isn't there a way to make the decoder itself have the kwargs ? That means better ownership of information. (overridding kwargs means the user now has to declare himself `decoder = pytctc.Decode(..., **kwargs); pipe = pipeline(..., decoder=decoder)` and at least who eats those arguments is extra clear.
- Adding them to the raw pipeline is like the `generate_kwargs`, not every argument can be changed in the future, and user has no idea if the argument was correctly passed. (Misnamed argument gets silently discarded)
- Other option if `decoder` doesn't own it is to have `pipeline(..., decoder_kwargs={..})`. This is cleaner as it adds only 1 kwargs and it's unlikely to be miss attributed. However, those are not "owned" by the decoder itself, meaning the behavior is pipeline specific. Going that route the arguments to pipelines are going to get extremely long (they already are).
label: Design

message: In that case, I'm confused as to why this was changed at all, since it already captured everything including the "configuration" tags.  The changes lead me to believe that it's trying to capture stuff when the "configuration" element is missing.  Or maybe it's trying to capture other stuff that's inside of "data", but outside of "configuration".  If so, it only captures stuff up to and including "configuration"; it won't capture anything that appears after the "configuration" element.  So given "<data><hello>world</hello><configuration>abc</configuration><after>bye</after></data>", it will capture "<hello>world</hello><configuration>abc</configuration>" and will not capture "<after>bye</after>".

message: > all cases check whether the secret change, but this one does not.  > Is there a reason for that? Yes, it did, because that secret was in a different TLV. Here's a workaround for rails 4.1 (+postgres) users who want to use `maintain_test_schema!` in the meantime, while we wait for 4.2.

```ruby
# Put in spec_helper, before call to ActiveRecord::Migration.maintain_test_schema!
if ActiveRecord::Migrator.needs_migration?
  puts('Needs migrations, purging test database ..')
  ActiveRecord::Tasks::PostgreSQLDatabaseTasks
    .new(ActiveRecord::Base.configurations.fetch('test'))
    .purge
end
```

@Taragolis:

>I thought IDE warn because it decide that `RunJobFlowInputRequestTypeDef` not suitable for dict.update

Yep, the warning was similar to that. The exact warning was `Expected type 'Mapping[_KT, _VT]', got 'RunJobFlowInputRequestTypeDef'` instead

 

>`job_flow_overrides` might not be `RunJobFlowInputRequestTypeDef`

According to the docs in that PR (and confirmed by the [usage](https://github.com/apache/airflow/blob/fb741fd87254e235f99d7d67e558dafad601f253/airflow/providers/amazon/aws/hooks/emr.py#L121-L123) of job_flow_overrides), the result after overriding will be used in the boto3 emr client `run_job_flow` method. So, any values used in `job_flow_overrides` needs to be a subset of the possible values from `RunJobFlowInputRequestTypeDef`.

Please let me know if I'm missing something.

message:
I think you'd want to mention in here that operators should be careful about changing this on a compute service that is hosting instances because that could cause rebuilds to fail (rebuild on the compute calls _prep_block_device which will do the max check, so if I've got an existing server with 26 volumes attached, the operator thinks 20 is a good max number for some reason, and then I rebuild my server, it's going to fail - similarly but probably less annoying to the user would be if evacuation fails because moving from one host to another fails because the target host is configured with a lower number).

Now that I'm thinking about evacuate (move operations), I don't see anything in here that enforces this for migrate operations so I could create a server with let's say 25 volumes on host A, and then be migrated to host B which is configured with max=10, and it would work even though my server is violating that constraint. Granted, if you're going to set this ever, you're probably going to do it universally, or at least on hosts with similar hardware and grouped into aggregates or something similar, so it's less of a concern. I could just see someone reporting a bug about that in the future.
label: Design

message:
`forward` should be called. It's just that `forward` is defined in `base` vs subclasses, just because of the `ensure_on_device` + `no_grad` wrappers that are important.

`_forward` on the other hand does not contain those guards.

`preprocess` > `forward` > `postprocess` : valid and recommended
`preprocess` > `_forward` > `postprocess` : valid but slower (no grad guards) + no GPU out of the box. (Important to keep readability within pipeline to a max.)

The only problem I've found is if a trailing slash is meant to be part of the query string, such as "?spareslashes=////" where I expect the value of spareslashes to be "////". I can't really think of a reason someone would do this (maybe putting another path to redirect to later?), but it seems RFC 3986 allows it (specifically section 3.4... "The characters slash ("/") and question mark ("?") may represent data within the query component."). If this is the case it would seem that the slash could conceivably come at the end of a query string somehow. What does everyone think?

message:
If you throw this into an initializer it will apply this fix until something is in Rails:

```
module ActionDispatch
  class Request < Rack::Request
    def deep_munge(hash)
      hash.each do |k, v|
        case v
        when Array
          if v.size > 0 && v.all?(&:nil?)
            hash[k] = nil
            next
          end
          v.grep(Hash) { |x| deep_munge(x) }
          v.compact!
        when Hash
          deep_munge(v)
        end
      end

      hash
    end
  end
end
```

If you still need ```{"test": [nil]}``` to work, it won't but ```{"test": []}``` will, which was enough of a fix for my applications.

Yeah so this was inspired by the Megatron code - the dividing by layer index was a heuristic to prevent overflow in FP16, which we ran into a few times training the Mistral GPT-2 small and medium models.

The `baddbmm` in the lines below actually applies the scaling value to the keys prior to the QK multiply. We chose not to re-multiply by layer_idx -- it changes the semantics a bit, but doesn't affect performance.
label: Functionality

message:
This should also break when the cutoff_eos_index is larger than the length of the remaining input. Otherwise it fails because `input[cutoff_eos_index:]` returns an empty list, which cannot be indexed with `self.tokenizer.eos_token_id`.

An easy fix is the following, which could probably be made cleaner.

```suggestion
                    if cutoff_eos_index >= len(input):
                        break
                        
                    cutoff_eos_index = input[cutoff_eos_index:].index(self.tokenizer.eos_token_id)
                    if cutoff_eos_index == 0 or cutoff_eos_index == len(input) - 1:
                        break
                    else:
                        input = input[cutoff_eos_index + 1 :]
```
label: Functionality

message:
I think there are 2 options:
1) Subscribe all actors, don't establish connections immediately but only save actor info in a local map. Establish connections on demand when submitting actor tasks.
2) Don't subscribe anything initially. When receiving a new actor task,  look up actor info in gcs and establish a connection. And then also subscribe that particular actor.

Option 1 should have shorter latency, but option 2 can subscribe less data. I'm not too sure which one would be better. They both sound fine to me.

BTW, we can add a method in `ActorStateAccessor` that subscribes a given actor. That change should be simple, because we only need to do `RequestNotification` in that method.
label: Design

I've always found passing `**kwargs` here strange. I guess it's useful for weird Optimizer implementations which violate the Liskov Substitution Principle.

One way we could get around it is doing

```python
    @runtime_checkable
    class _Optimizer(Protocol):
        def step(self, closure: Callable[[], Any], **kwargs: Any) -> Any:
            ...

    def optimizer_step(
        self,
        model: Union["pl.LightningModule", Module],
        optimizer: _Optimizer,
        optimizer_idx: int,
        closure: Callable[[], Any],
        **kwargs: Any,
    ) -> None:
```

Or maybe I'm just too excited about having learned a new thing and want to use it where I shouldn't.

Do you have any thoughts about this @ananthsub?

I was sharing the same feeling, but I'm testing something that is related to the testing environment, which is a kind of special case.

By overwriting these methods, I want to be sure to control the `_test_serialized_contents` data during the whole test. It is important to mock them also in `TestSerializedRollbackInhibitsPostMigrate` test.

If we don't mock it, the logic here tries to load some data from previous django test suite serialized contents (because the test suite has some initial data migrations), which is adding some dependencies between tests in the test suite.

This mock should be done every time we want to test something with `TransactionTestCase` and `serialized_rollback = True` to avoid test dependencies. Maybe some documentation to explain it would be nice.

message:
Using ResourceProviderUpdateFailed as an example, I find it pretty hard to track and confirm that there is a log of some kind when such an error happens. I did find a LOG.error near the two places where it is raised, so there is some audit-ability, but it might be hard to associate that log message with the exception raised here because we're swallowing the first one and this second one is not explicitly caught and logged when _update is called, it just percolates out as part of the top-level exception handling in place to keep the long-running process alive.

Not necessarily here, but at some point, we may wish to pass the helper_exception as exc into ResourceProviderSyncFailed so when that top-level logging happens, we have some association. Or we may wish to do some logging here.

Failures during periodic jobs and the RPC handlers tend to be terribly hard to debug for people out there, so the more noise we can get into the logs the better.

That said, this particular situation isn't so much a failure as one of several expected ways in which things can temporarily go wrong that will be fixed later. However, if things get into a situation where the excepted things keep happening (perhaps because of concurrency issues) we will need lots of log in order to have any visibility.
label: Design

message:
So this is what we have to remove the stubs in:

```ruby
def setup
  @fake_timezones = %w(A B C D E).map do |id|
    tz = stub(:name => id, :to_s => id)
    ActiveSupport::TimeZone.stubs(:[]).with(id).returns(tz)
    tz
  end
  ActiveSupport::TimeZone.stubs(:all).returns(@fake_timezones)
end
```

I think this should do:

```ruby
module FakeZones
  FakeZone = Struct.new(:name) do
    def to_s; name; end
  end

  ZONES_BY_ID = %(A B C D E).map { |id| [ id, FakeZone.new(id) ] }.to_h

  def [](id); use_fake_zones ? ZONES_BY_ID[id] : super; end
  def all; use_fake_zones ? ZONES_BY_ID : super; end

  def self.prepended(base)
    base.class_eval do
      mattr_accessor(:use_fake_zones) { false }
    end
  end
end

ActiveSupport::TimeZone.prepend FakeZones

setup do
  @fake_timezones = FakeZones::ZONES_BY_ID.values
  ActiveSupport::TimeZone.use_fake_zones = true
end

teardown do
  ActiveSupport::TimeZone.use_fake_zones = false
end
```

You're way too quick to grab onto those stubs and mocks. Don't be afraid to get more creative with Ruby :wink:

nit: here and above, rather than pin this for the entire test, we could do:

with utils.temporary_mutation(self.api, microversion='2.67):
    self.api.post_server_action(server['id'], post)

And that could be done in a private helper method:

def _force_evacuate(self, server_id, request_body):
    with utils.temporary_mutation(self.api, microversion='2.67):

message:
I see. The code makes sense to me now. thanks. 

2 small remaining issues: 

1. the logic in `has_batch` can be optimized as the following. Because when `self._materialized_size() >= self._min_buffer_size `, we can take a batch directly from the buffer without trigger compaction. this should only improve latency, not throughput. 

```
           self._materialized_size() >= self._min_buffer_size  or (
                buffer_size - self._batch_size
                >= self._buffer_min_size * SHUFFLE_BUFFER_COMPACTION_RATIO
            )
 ```
 
 2. With compact ratio = 1.5, if we change the batch_size to 800 for the benchmark. The code will crash due to the `can_add` issue I mentioned before. better add a test with different combinations of batch_size + min_buffer_size.

message:
For those who need this fix badly, here's my monkey patch. :monkey: put it in `config/initializers/patches.rb`

```ruby
# unscope on preload fix: https://github.com/rails/rails/pull/17360
abort 'This patch should be removed after 4.1.8' unless Rails.version == '4.1.8'
module ActiveRecord
  module Associations
    class Preloader
      class Association #:nodoc:
        def build_scope
          scope = klass.unscoped

          values         = reflection_scope.values
          preload_values = preload_scope.values

          scope.where_values      = Array(values[:where])      + Array(preload_values[:where])
          scope.references_values = Array(values[:references]) + Array(preload_values[:references])

          scope._select!   preload_values[:select] || values[:select] || table[Arel.star]
          scope.includes! preload_values[:includes] || values[:includes]

          if preload_values.key? :order
            scope.order! preload_values[:order]
          else
            if values.key? :order
              scope.order! values[:order]
            end
          end

          if options[:as]
            scope.where!(klass.table_name => { reflection.type => model.base_class.sti_name })
          end

          scope.unscope_values = Array(values[:unscope])
          klass.default_scoped.merge(scope)
        end
      end
    end
  end
end

```

message:
We shouldn't be calling `from_pretrained` in the `__init__` -> the `__init__` is reserved for defining our modules/models rather than loadin pre-trained weights. Also, we wan't to leave flexibility for using other audio encoding models, not just Encodec.

What we should do here is something similar to BLIP-2, where we load Encodec through an AutoModel class: https://github.com/huggingface/transformers/blob/8e164c5400b7b413c7b8fb32e35132001effc970/src/transformers/models/blip_2/modeling_blip_2.py#L1234

So here, this would look something like:
```python
self.codec_model = AutoModel.from_config(config.codec_config)
```

Where `codec_config` is the config for the codec model, which for the pre-trained model will be the config for the base Encodec model

message:
We've discussed this PR today with @senny and we also don't quite see this extension.

The use case is of course valid, and the proposal itself would technically work, it is more a matter of how we want to evolve this API. And the idea is that we see this API as being small and simple as it is.

A lambda would open a door in what is a compact API for a extremely sensible feature. That lambda should deal with the case where `:type` has been hacked. Because when you are in a strong params context the assumption is that you are being hacked, the golden path should be exceptional in your way of coding. As a rule of thumb, we want strong params to take care of those things. Users declare, strong params protect. So we prefer to keep the interface small and simple.

In general, all valid uses cases not directly covered by the API that have been showing up all this time have been addressed [documenting a way to solve them using Ruby](http://guides.rubyonrails.org/action_controller_overview.html#more-examples). In this use case, some code would dynamically decide what to declare, and then it would pass that to `permit`. Perhaps this could also be added to that guide section.
label: Response

I don't really think we should merge anything like this. Any difference in how these files get laid out on disk could cause this to fail to detect properly. In a frozen environment (not sure if the win32 people run like that or not) then this is also likely to be different.

However, the fact that we need to do this is part of why I'm highly concerned with just doing this globally -- it's a pretty core piece of functionality that everything we import into our process will choke on. Maybe in obvious ways like this, but maybe not. What if I have a polling loop in some library that wraps a sleep and a poll and catches ValueError for the poll? That library will behave very strangely and non-obviously, only in these tests and for a very obscure reason.

message:
Currently `is_type_comment()` takes a `suffix` argument, which is always passed as either `""` or `" ignore"`. Calls that use the former should stay as `is_type_coment()`, and calls that use the latter use `is_type_ignore_comment()`.

What's deprecated-ish is using type comments for type annotations like `x: []  # type: List[str]`. This was a compatibility feature introduced in PEP 484 for compatibility with Python 2 and Python 3.5, but it's not needed in modern versions of Python. Therefore, we're thinking of deprecating mypy support for it: python/mypy#12947. However, `# type: ignore` has no such replacement and it's here to stay.

message:
Hey @Rajathbharadwaj,

I meant something like this

```py
# rank_zero_warning of type UserWarning for max_epochs if not set
if self.max_epochs is None and max_steps == -1 and max_time is None:
    rank_zero_warn(
        "`max_epochs` is not set. By default it will run for 1000 epochs.",
        UserWarning,
    )

fit_loop = FitLoop(
    min_epochs=(1 if (min_epochs is None and min_steps is None and max_time is None) else min_epochs),
    max_epochs=(
    max_epochs if max_epochs is not None else (1000 if (max_steps == -1 and max_time is None) else -1)
),
)
```

could become

# trainer.py
```py
min_epochs, max_epochs = _parse_min_and_max_epochs(max_steps, max_epochs, max_time, min_steps, min_epochs)

fit_loop = FitLoop(min_epochs=min_epochs, max_epochs= max_epochs)

# utilities/...
def _parse_max_epochs_and_steps(max_steps, max_epochs, max_time, min_steps, min_epochs):
    if max_epochs is None and max_steps == -1 and max_time is None:
        rank_zero_warn(
            "`max_epochs` is not set. By default it will run for 1000 epochs.",
            UserWarning,
        )
    min_epochs = (1 if (min_epochs is None and min_steps is None and max_time is None) else min_epochs)
    max_epochs = max_epochs if max_epochs is not None else (1000 if (max_steps == -1 and max_time is None) else -1)
    return min_epochs, max_epochs
```

We have a method to get all disabled users (`all_disabled`) and this one - to get all enabled users. But in some cases we need all enabled users, and sometimes - only active or only pending. So I added parameter `is_invitation_pending` which is a filter: 

- `is_invitation_pending=None` - fetch all
- `is_invitation_pending=False` - only active
- `is_invitation_pending=True` - only pending.

I don't know what is the right way to create API like this; this implementation works as I need, so ATM we have what we have. But I'll appreciate any suggestions for improving this.

message:
The difference is that both axes of an ROC curve have constant denominators:
* `fpr = fps / fps[-1]` (linearly correlated with `fps`)
* `tpr = tps / tps[-1]` (linearly correlated with `tps`) 

By contrast, `precision` has a non-constant denominator (note that `recall = tpr`): 
* `precision = tps / (tps + fps)` (not linearly correlated with either `tps` or `fps`)

---

If you extend your example by one to `tps = [1, 2, 3, 3, 3, 5, 6, 7]`, then you will get:

```
tps = [1, 3, 3, 3, 5, 6, 7]
fps = [0, 0, 1, 2, 2, 2, 2]
tpr = [1/7, 3/7, 3/7, 3/7, 5/7, 6/7, 7/7]
fpr = [0/2, 0/2, 1/2, 2/2, 2/2, 2/2, 2/2]
precision = [1/1, 3/3, 3/4, 3/5, 5/7, 6/8, 7/9]
```

`np.r_[True, np.logical_or(np.diff(tps[:-1]), np.diff(tps[1:])), True]` results in `[1, 3, 3, 5, 6, 7]`.

`np.r_[True, np.diff(tps, 2), True]` results in `[1, 3, 3, 5, 7]`.

The second method incorrectly drops the 6, which is not actually on a line in the precision-recall curve:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/2308172/196274643-42dd8ea8-2bb6-49b6-9538-a686c191354c.png)
label: Functionality

message: I'm more inclined to logging to the error output stream. I believe it's more suitable for this kind of messages.  We can redirect `StatusPrinter` to `System.err`, but also should have bear in mind that `StatusPrinter` for some reason is static, so we should restore it to `System.out` after using. How about making the output stream as a field of `LoggingFactory`? Something like this:  ``` java @JsonIgnore                                          private final PrintStream configurationErrorsStream; ... @VisibleForTesting LoggingFactory(LoggerContext loggerContext, PrintStream configurationErrorsStream) {     this.loggerContext = checkNotNull(loggerContext);     this.errorsStream = checkNotNull(configurationErrorsStream); } ...  StatusPrinter.setPrintStream(configurationErrorsStream); try {     printIfErrorsOccured(loggerContext); }  finally {    StatusPrinter.setPrintStream(System.out);  } ```  As a benefit, we can pass a fake stream in the test to the class in the constructor.

message:
After looking into the history, :-1: entirely. `RACK_ENV` grew out of a Rack server convention that multiple servers supported, then Rack::Server included. The fact that Rack::Server happened to have these default middleware stacks doesn't imply that it's the only allowed values, the only intended values, or part of the `SPEC` :grin: 

There's a long history of using `RACK_ENV` to communicate exactly what it is: the environment you're running the Rack *app* in, not the *Rack environment*.

We've discussed the wording briefly and @pixeltrix came up with the following suggestion:

```
  # Returns the number of seconds that this Duration represents.
  #
  #   1.minute.to_i   # => 60
  #   1.hour.to_i     # => 3600
  #   1.day.to_i      # => 86400
  #
  # Note that this conversion makes some assumptions about the
  # duration of some periods, e.g. months are always 30 days
  # and years are 365.25 days:
  #
  #   # equivalent to 30.days.to_i
  #   1.month.to_i    # => 2592000
  #
  #   # equivalent to 365.25.days.to_i
  #   1.year.to_i     # => 31557600
  #
  # In such cases, Ruby's core
  # Date[http://ruby-doc.org/stdlib/libdoc/date/rdoc/Date.html] and
  # Time[http://ruby-doc.org/stdlib/libdoc/time/rdoc/Time.html] should be used for precision
  # date and time arithmetic.
  def to_i
    @value.to_i
  end
```

@nerdinand what do you think?

message: No, it is checking whether the *transition* (not the next (target) state) is allowed based on the *state* stored in "dumper".  Intended transition: - Previous state: JSON_DUMPER_TYPE_BASE64 - Transition: JSON_DUMPER_END (for JSON_DUMPER_TYPE_BASE64) - Next state: JSON_DUMPER_TYPE_VALUE (meaning: value is set)  Compare this to json_dumper_end_object: - Previous state: JSON_DUMPER_TYPE_OBJECT, JSON_DUMPER_TYPE_NONE - Transition: JSON_DUMPER_END (for JSON_DUMPER_TYPE_OBJECT) - Next state: (final state)

message:
They aren't necessarily symmetric, despite the names of the methods.

It turns out that `#strict_*` implement RFC 4648 whereas the other methods implement RFC 2045.

RFC 2045 decoding of RFC 4648-encoded messages works fine. But we should use `#strict_*` for both :+1:

So I did try this out as well, and the test actually throws an exception. 

```
$ trial tests.test_downloader_handlers.Http11ProxyTestCase.test_download_with_proxy_without_http_scheme
tests.test_downloader_handlers
  Http11ProxyTestCase
    test_download_with_proxy_without_http_scheme ...                    [ERROR]

===============================================================================
[ERROR]
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "scrapy\tests\test_downloader_handlers.py", line 746, in test_download_with_proxy_without_http_scheme
    return self.download_request(request, Spider('foo')).addCallback(_test)
  File "scrapy\scrapy\core\downloader\handlers\http11.py", line 88, in download_request
    return agent.download_request(request)
  File "scrapy\scrapy\core\downloader\handlers\http11.py", line 341, in download_request
    agent = self._get_agent(request, timeout)
  File "scrapy\scrapy\core\downloader\handlers\http11.py", line 300, in _get_agent
    _, _, proxyHost, proxyPort, proxyParams = _parse(proxy)
  File "scrapy\scrapy\core\downloader\webclient.py", line 36, in _parse
    return _parsed_url_args(parsed)
  File "scrapy\scrapy\core\downloader\webclient.py", line 19, in _parsed_url_args
    host = to_bytes(parsed.hostname, encoding="ascii")
  File "scrapy\scrapy\utils\python.py", line 104, in to_bytes
    raise TypeError('to_bytes must receive a str or bytes '
builtins.TypeError: to_bytes must receive a str or bytes object, got NoneType

tests.test_downloader_handlers.Http11ProxyTestCase.test_download_with_proxy_without_http_scheme
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Ran 1 tests in 0.102s

FAILED (errors=1)
```

It seems like the reason is `urllib.parse.urlparse` internal implementation

```
>>> from urllib.parse import urlparse
>>> parsed = urlparse('test-uri.com')
>>> parsed.hostname
>>> parsed.hostname == None
True
parsed = urlparse('//test-uri.com')
>>> parsed.hostname
'test-uri.com'
```

message: That's what I was hoping to do, but couldn't due to the storm and backtype `TopologyContext` class and how they use `MetricsDelegate`. It needs to know both the class that extends `IMetric` (T) and the type of metric (U), since it takes an `IMetric` delegate and returns the return type.  ``` public class TopologyContext ... {   ...   public <T extends IMetric<U>, U> T registerMetric(String name,                                                     T metric,                                                     int timeBucketSizeInSecs) {     MetricDelegate<T, U> d = new MetricDelegate<>(metric);     delegate.registerMetric(name, d, timeBucketSizeInSecs);     return metric;   } ```  ``` public class MetricDelegate<T extends IMetric<U>, U>     implements com.twitter.heron.api.metric.IMetric<U> {   private T delegate;    public MetricDelegate(T delegate) {     this.delegate = delegate;   }    @Override   public U getValueAndReset() {     return delegate.getValueAndReset();   } } ```

message:
I think it would be useful to document this function, because I do not think it is obvious how to use it. It would also be useful to move it into a benchmarking library.

If I understand correctly, the `funcs` are already specialized to the `param_list`, in that exact order, but the latter are passed in along with `param_names` only for printing purposes. Wouldn't the following alternate API be easier to use, because it would encapsulate the specialization of the benchmark function to the list of parameters, along with the 
construction of the specialized function name?

```
benchmark_suite(prepare: Callable[[Dict], Callable], params_list: List[Dict], name: str):
 """Benchmarks a function for several combinations of parameters.

 Args:
    prepare: given kwargs returns a benchmark function specialized to the kwargs. 
    params_list: a list of kwargs on which to run the benchmark.
    name: the name of this benchmark suite
 """ 
```
label: Documentation

message:
Hi - it looks like there are some errors when `JAX_ENABLE_X64=1` (you should be able to see the "Tests with internal numpy/scipy" failures in the CI list) One of the binary operations in this line is happening between two values that have mismatched types. We check for this in the test suite in order to support `jax_numpy_dtype_promotion='strict'` without false positives from library code.

I think the issue is that `lax_const` returns a numpy scalar, and so `2 * pi` is a numpy operation that promotes to float64. If you avoid the const and just write `2 * jnp.pi * lax.bessel_i0e(kappa)` I think it should fix the issue.

You can check the test locally with, e.g.
```
$ JAX_ENABLE_X64=1 pytest -n auto tests/scipy_stats_test.py -k VonMises
```

message:
Sorry that it takes so long to answer :relieved:.

The main idea was to provide an exact local path of the corresponding model checkpoint files that were uploaded. At our design level, there was some lack of information about how we should fully handle every behavior that ModelCheckpoint could provide. After that, at the implementation, we missed and messed something that it's got only applied to the best model.

I think it should be translated to something like `local_path` instead of `best_model_path` and be prepared for every last/k-best/best (especially be exactly right to every `cpkt` file). We would like to do some additional discussions to take proper care of it and I think it's out-of-scope for this PR. It may introduce new functionality or change the behavior instead of only bug-fixing.

message:
This is my benchmark attemp of ActiveSupport::XmlMini#to_tag to compare the current version with this PR
please CMIIW

```ruby
require "rails"
require "benchmark/ips"

Benchmark.ips do |x|
  x.config(time: 5, warmup: 2)
  x.report "Current #to_tag" do |n|
    n.times do
      ActiveSupport::XmlMini.to_tag "xml", { element: 1 }, { indent: 2 }
    end
  end

  module ActiveSupport
    module XmlMini
      def to_tag(key, value, options)
        type_name = options.delete(:type)
        options.merge!(:root => key, :skip_instruct => true)

        if value.is_a?(::Method) || value.is_a?(::Proc)
          if value.arity == 1
            value.call(options)
          else
            value.call(options, key.to_s.singularize)
          end
        elsif value.respond_to?(:to_xml)
          value.to_xml(options)
        else
          type_name ||= TYPE_NAMES[value.class.name]
          type_name ||= value.class.name if value && !value.respond_to?(:to_str)
          type_name   = type_name.to_s   if type_name
          type_name   = "dateTime" if type_name == "datetime"

          key = rename_key(key.to_s, options)

          attributes = options[:skip_types] || type_name.nil? ? { } : { :type => type_name }
          attributes[:nil] = true if value.nil?

          encoding = options[:encoding] || DEFAULT_ENCODINGS[type_name]
          attributes[:encoding] = encoding if encoding

          formatted_value = FORMATTING[type_name] && !value.nil? ?
            FORMATTING[type_name].call(value) : value

          options[:builder].tag!(key, formatted_value, attributes)
        end
      end
    end
  end
  x.report "17152 PR version" do |n|
    n.times do
      ActiveSupport::XmlMini.to_tag "xml", { element: 1}, { indent: 2}
    end
  end

  module ActiveSupport
    module XmlMini
      def to_tag(key, value, options)
        options = options.dup
        type_name = options.delete(:type)
        options.merge!(:root => key, :skip_instruct => true)

        if value.is_a?(::Method) || value.is_a?(::Proc)
          if value.arity == 1
            value.call(options)
          else
            value.call(options, key.to_s.singularize)
          end
        elsif value.respond_to?(:to_xml)
          value.to_xml(options)
        else
          type_name ||= TYPE_NAMES[value.class.name]
          type_name ||= value.class.name if value && !value.respond_to?(:to_str)
          type_name   = type_name.to_s   if type_name
          type_name   = "dateTime" if type_name == "datetime"

          key = rename_key(key.to_s, options)

          attributes = options[:skip_types] || type_name.nil? ? { } : { :type => type_name }
          attributes[:nil] = true if value.nil?

          encoding = options[:encoding] || DEFAULT_ENCODINGS[type_name]
          attributes[:encoding] = encoding if encoding

          formatted_value = FORMATTING[type_name] && !value.nil? ?
            FORMATTING[type_name].call(value) : value

          options[:builder].tag!(key, formatted_value, attributes)
        end
      end
    end
  end
  x.report "17152 PR dup version" do |n|
    n.times do
      ActiveSupport::XmlMini.to_tag "xml", { element: 1}, { indent: 2}
    end
  end

  x.compare!
end
```

### Output
```
Calculating -------------------------------------
     Current #to_tag   604.000  i/100ms
    17152 PR version   603.000  i/100ms
17152 PR dup version   603.000  i/100ms
-------------------------------------------------
     Current #to_tag      7.008k (± 1.6%) i/s -     35.032k
    17152 PR version      7.065k (± 0.8%) i/s -     35.577k
17152 PR dup version      7.028k (± 1.1%) i/s -     35.577k

Comparison:
    17152 PR version:     7065.3 i/s
17152 PR dup version:     7028.3 i/s - 1.01x slower
     Current #to_tag:     7007.6 i/s - 1.01x slower

```
result of the benchmark is this PR version have faster performance, but when we applied #dup at options argument, the result is same as current #to_tag performance

message:
This makes the current implementation not compatible with `accelerate` ideally we want to wrap the qkv in a `nn.Linear` layer and call the forward pass without using `nn.functional.linear`. Something like [this](https://github.com/younesbelkada/transformers/blob/blip-2-accelerate/src/transformers/models/blip_2/modeling_blip_2.py#L142-L153) should work but we may want to create `qkv_bias` on the fly inside the `forward` to avoid state_dict errors when loading the current weights from the Hub (i.e. with the patch above, since we assign a new value to `qkv.bias` it will be counted as a new parameters, hence considered as an expected key from the state_dict)
We can also put `r".*.qkv.bias"` in `_keys_to_ignore_on_missing` but not sure if this is a good approach

I think it has to do with `accepts_nested_attributes_for` (aside: I never liked that feature when it was added, never use it, so I'm not that familiar with it). Looking at that commit I mentioned earlier, just guessing here: suppose a model is like this:

```
class Bird < ActiveRecord::Base
   belongs_to :pirate
   accepts_nested_attributes_for :pirate
end
```

Suppose you want to update an existing Bird which has pirate_id 987. Suppose this is posted:

```
  :pirate_id => 12345, :pirate_attributes => {:id => 12345, :catchphrase => 'Holla!'}
```

In this case it's important that pirate_id is first applied before the pirate_attributes are applied.

message:
Does this problem only exist when both sides use `dependent: :destroy`, or also when one side uses `dependent: :destroy` and the other side has a manual destroy before/after hook?

Because I can think of the following example:

```ruby
class Post < ActiveRecord::Base
  has_many :comments, dependent: :destroy
end

class Comment < ActiveRecord::Base
  belongs_to :post

  after_destroy do
    post.destroy if post.comments.none?
  end
end
```

(The idea being, you are modelling a message board post+comment, where the post contains the overall thread subject, but the body of a new user-submitted post is saved as the first comment created at same time as the post itself. Then, either the whole post can get deleted, or all the comments can get deleted, and if they do, the parent post should be implicitly deleted as well.

message: My comment regarding value 0 was not addressed / answered. By default 3GPP SMS-C do not use ASCII as coding scheme, but 7 bits GSM encoding, so this seems wrong. The usual alphabets used in 3GPP TS 23.038 are GSM 7 bit default alphabet, 8 bits data (which is not used for ASCII but to transfer binary payload) and UCS2. SMPP specification 5.0 says for value 0: "This represents the default alphabet assumed by the MC. This coding scheme may differ from vendor to vendor or may vary according to location and network technology of MC. For portability of applications, it is strongly recommended to avoid using this setting." So we must add a preference (defaulting to not decoding) allowing to select the alphabet to be used within a list (with the alphabets in this function to start with, and GSM 7 bits alphabet and ASCII also)
label: Support

message: getRowCount() may return a different number of rows than the actual bootstrap is seeing. Consider the following scenario: 1. 1 million records in table. 2. getRowCount() returns 1 million 3. insertBootstrapStartRow() 4. 1 million rows deleted by outside process 5. Maxwell sees the bootstrap start row. 6. Maxwell does a "select *" and inserts 0 rows into the stream. 7. Maxwell marks the bootstrap row as completed.  insertedRowsCount will always be 0. This while loop will never set isComplete and will block forever.

message:
This is not a problem that the Rails team should, in my opinion, be responsible for solving, but it feels worth adding a comment here in case other people come across the same issue. This change causes a test suite to start failing because of an issue with, I believe, phantomjs.

I wrote up a full description at https://github.com/ariya/phantomjs/issues/13110 but here's a summary for future bug hunters...

With HTTP 409 Conflict responses, ajax requests (e.g., with jQuery's `$.ajax`) started having a `jqXHR.status` value of `0` (and a `readyState` of `0`) in the `error` handler function. This broke JavaScript that needs to check that `status === 409` in our application.

message: I'm trying to convince myself that it's benign not to handle the pending abort here. I guess the old behavior was to do an exception checkpoint once we're out of the outermost dynamic endfinally. I think in normal control flow this just delays the interrupt check until some later instruction.  The thing I'm unsure about is when the finally clause is called by the exception handler. In that case we'll unwind this finally and potentially have an unhandled exn instead of a thread abort. I'm not sure the unwinder does any interrupt check on its own.

message: I'm actually trying to shrink the size of `ArtifactsBusinessLogic` and to encapsulate the state of `ArtifactDataDefinition` (in other words to prevent unnecessary exposure of its state). In the future, this method may be a private one. The overall goal is to maximize the "Tell don't ask" principle and the Law of Demeter:  - https://martinfowler.com/bliki/TellDontAsk.html - https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Law_of_Demeter - https://pragprog.com/articles/tell-dont-ask - https://softwareengineering.stackexchange.com/questions/157526/explanation-on-how-tell-dont-ask-is-considered-good-oo  So for now, could we keep this as is until we get a better idea about the behaviors assigned to `ArtifactDataDefinition`? Maybe we'll figure out another object but for now I rather centralize what interacts with its state, and to encapsulate whatever possible.
label: Design
